citation.article-title: Salisaeta longa gen. nov., sp. nov., a red, halophilic member of the Bacteroidetes
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Salisaeta longa sp. nov.
Salisaeta longa (lon′ga. L. fem. adj. longa long).
Displays the following properties in addition to those described for the genus.
Straight or slightly curved rods, 15–30 μm long.
Colonies on agar are red, circular and convex with an entire margin.
Pigment extracts in methanol/acetone (1 : 1, v/v) show an absorption maximum at 478 nm and a shoulder at 506–510 nm.
Grows optimally at 10 % NaCl plus 5 % MgCl2 . 6H2O.
Tolerates 20 % MgCl2 . 6H2O.
The optimal pH for growth is 6.5–8.5; no growth below pH 6.0 or above pH 9.0.
Temperature optimum is 37–46 °C; no growth above 50 °C or below 25 °C.
Nitrate is not reduced.
Glucose, sucrose, maltose and glycerol stimulate growth with acid formation.
No growth stimulation or acid formation is obtained in the presence of ribose, xylose, mannitol or sorbitol; fructose causes acidification of the medium, but does not stimulate growth.
Starch and gelatin are weakly hydrolysed.
Indole is produced from tryptophan.
Sensitive to penicillin G, ampicillin, novobiocin and rifampicin.
Insensitive to streptomycin, neomycin, bacitracin and anisomycin.
Polar lipids include three glycolipids and four major phospholipids, one of which contains an amino group.
Main fatty acids are 16 : 0 iso and 16 : 1 cis9, followed by 15 : 0 iso and 15 : 0 anteiso.
The type strain is strain S4-4T (=DSM 21114T =CECT 7354T), isolated from an experimental mesocosm filled with a mixture of water from the Dead Sea and the Red Sea, Israel.
